author: Ben Glaze
title: Private care firms' shareholders 'cash in' from £2billion extra funding in the Budget
text:
News Private care firms' shareholders 'cash in' from £2billion extra funding in the Budget The New Economics Foundation says £115million of the injection will go straight to into the wallets of investors in the five biggest care chains Share Philip Hammond announced the funding in Wednesday's Budget (Photo: Getty) Share Get politics   Thank you for subscribing!   
Shareholders in private care firms are set to cash in from the Chancellor’s £2billion Budget pledge, research reveals today. 
Philip Hammond bowed to growing calls for fresh funds to ease pressure on stretched social care services when he announced the money in the Commons. 
But the New Economics Foundation says £115million of the injection will go straight to into the wallets of investors in the five biggest care chains. 
A fifth of all publicly funded care homes in the UK are provided by the companies, according to the think tank. Read More 
And 29p in every pound funnelled to the firms is pumped into their shareholders’ pockets. The country's bill for care is rocketing (Photo: REX/Shutterstock) 
That translates to £115million of the money promised in the Budget for social care going to shareholders and bondholders in the five biggest care providers. 
New Economics Foundation Chief Executive Marc Stears said: “Everyone knows our social care system desperately needs cash. 
“But far too much of the £2billion the Chancellor promised will go straight into the pockets of private investors rather than to the beds and services people need. 
“The Government could put a stop to it now by making sure big care providers offer more reasonable returns to their investors. 
“That way more of the much-needed cash promised this week would go towards frontline services. 
“It’s time we built a care system that puts people, and not investors, in control.” 
Mr Hammond has said the Government will publish options later this year for a long-term overhaul of social care. Philip Hammond promised more long-term solutions in his Budget (Photo: AFP) 
The NEF wants it to include a 5% cap on the amount care firms can pay to investors. 
And it calls for a shake-up so the industry has more small care homes with up to 10 patients rather than big “factory farms” housing scores of OAPs. 
Policy chief Sarah Lyall added: “Our social care system will soon be dominated by a handful of chain care providers offering low-quality care. 
“We deserve better than this investor-driven factory farm operation. Unless we take action now, millions will end up suffering at the hands of a system that values neither our dignity in old age nor our lifelong tax contributions. 
“While the extra funding for social care is desperately needed, we urgently need to do the hard work of reforming how care is delivered. 
“The Government’s review of social care must set out how we can support a network of smaller care providers, putting dignity back into the services our friends, neighbours and relatives depend on.” Read More
